project.name: ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက
project.description:
​℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက is about identity; both individual identity as well as our collective identity as a species.

Since the very beginning, human beings have been fascinated by the world around them. We have tried to understand it, our place in it, and ourselves. In this process, faced with chaotic complexity and forces we couldn't comprehend, we gave significance to otherwise meaningless events, and created a meaningful world for ourselves within the greater unfathomable universe. 

Things do not have names, nor exist in inherent categories. Humans are responsible for these... We are the inventors of meaning.

With this in mind, I present my own creation: ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက

I'm a single human, attempting to be humanity itself in my own analogy, with my creation as a metaphor for all we have created.

℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက is an ever-evolving artwork that focuses on the experience of existing as a human being; our grappling with the apparent chaos we find ourselves in and our constant attempts at finding order and meaning in this chaos.

And just like our lives, there are random, meaningless elements in it, there are deliberate, purposeful elements in it, and there are elements that depend on your interpretation as to whether they have any meaning or not. ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက asks you: Do things have inherent meaning, or are they empty of it until human beings consider them worthy of consideration? And it dares you to find meaning for your own life in it.

Thus, when you look at your ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက, you will have questions about the meaning of its elements, just as we have questions about the meaning of everything we experience, including our own existence. And while all the answers to the latter might not ever be fully understood, the answers to the former can be found with the help of one of humanity's greatest modern inventions: the internet. Whether this then goes on to help you find meaning in your own life is up to you.

Any attempt at describing ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက without mentioning Matt Kane's "Gazers" would be incomplete. In both a literal and figurative sense, Gazers are what gave birth to ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက. Literally, because it was while reading the art description of Gazers that the idea for ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက came to me. Figuratively, because if Gazers represent any one thing at all, that thing is nature, while ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက represents humans and their experiences. And through evolution by natural selection, humans were born from, and are a part of, nature.

It could be said that ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက is a kind of mirrored-reflection of Gazers. It focuses on and celebrates general subjective human learning and perception of reality, while Gazers' weave a delightful tapestry of light and time of which we humans partake of as entranced observers. 

Gazers ask questions about the future based upon observations of the past, and evolve according to specific rhythms in nature, using deterministic design rules upon their creation to determine all future evolution. ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက, on the other hand, asks no questions about the future, but rather focuses exclusively on the present, and how it has been influenced by the past. It asks, "How is today important?"

℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက's evolution is inspired by the lives of humans, as well as by the arbitrary, irregular clock of that which humans give importance to. Thus its deterministic design rules give the illusion of random evolution, as well as celebrate sporadic points in time determined beforehand, mimicking how human lives seem to progress chaotically except for certain moments in our lives that feel like "destiny". 

These moments only seem this way, however, with hindsight - when we look back, see our own personal story, and try to make sense of it. In the same way, ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက will change according to celebrated dates in the past from the date they were created, regardless of whether those days continue to be recognised or remembered in the future.

This pseudo-random evolution is also meant to be an analogy for compatibilism when it comes to free will. Compatibilism says that even though everything, past and future, is all predetermined, we can still act with free agency in what we perceive as the present moment. In the same way, all the randomness of the colours, characters and positionings of the characters of ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက are hard-coded in. But when actually looking at the work in the present, all these elements seem to change randomly.

In the end, humans and their culture all still fall under the great umbrella that is nature/the natural world. As much as our ancestors tried to deny it, we are as much a part of nature as the lowliest slimes - we just follow different rhythms, and at its core, this is what ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက is a celebration of: The wonderful fact of our existence as a result of simple, natural processes in the natural world, and our unique complexity that is so remarkable as to fool itself (ourselves) into thinking that we're something apart.

​For information about what each element in ℈ℽ⍷-ᚤက symbolises, visit : mandelsage.com/eye-am

project.name: Esthétique Quantique
project.description:
Crafting the Chaos of Order in a Deterministic Dance of Pixels

made with love by Genix

project.name: Vortex
project.description:
Vortex is an extraordinary collection of 50 generative artworks that capture the unique essence of the black hole and the particles through innovative algorithmic techniques. These works are the result of a masterful fusion of mathematics and creativity, resulting in an exceptional visual experience.

Each work consists of a set of particles moving seemingly randomly yet structured on a black background, reminiscent of a dark and mysterious universe. The particles move gracefully and fluidly, creating a sense of perpetual motion, similar to that of a black hole that attracts everything it encounters.

The color palette used in this collection is equally captivating. A deep and vibrant color, generated randomly by a function that returns a hexadecimal value, contrasts with the black background, evoking the reflection of light on a metallic surface or the contrast between hot and cold. This color blends and overlaps in a way that imparts a feeling of calm and serenity to the works.

Each work is unique, but they all share a hypnotic quality that captures the viewer and transports them into a world of abstract beauty. The number of moving particles and their positions constantly change, creating a sense of evolution and alteration, similar to that of the cosmic cycles.

The artist has skillfully harnessed the algorithm to capture the magic and complexity of the black hole and the particles, creating works that seem to come to life. When viewing these works, one can almost hear the sound of emptiness and perceive the gravitational force.

Vortex is a collection that invites viewers to reflect on the beauty of the universe and its immeasurable importance. These generative artworks serve as a reminder of how precious our planet is and inspire us to preserve and protect the spatial ecosystems. Ultimately, this collection is a tribute to the wonder of nature and a celebration of generative art as a means to explore the beauty and complexity of the world around us.

project.name: Estelas (Grave stelae)
project.description:
Covid generated an enormous number of deaths. I have painted, in acrylic, a large format work honoring the deceased. 
https://jmp54.com/ImgLienzos/covid2022.jpg

During the lockdown period, I was introduced to generative art on demand. I start making works in this new format. 

Funerary Stelae have been used in the Near East, Mesopotamia, Greece, Egypt, Somalia, Eritrea, Ethiopia…

The work of art Estelas tries to make the same recognition to those who died from the covid-19. 

The idea is to digitally paint faces using trails of the virus. 

These faces are a tribute to those deceased people. 

The faces are sketches of what those people were. The sketches represent how the trail of covid-19 deconstructs the real image of the individual. 

Thus, attention is now fixed on: the plasticity, the simplicity of the line and the combination of colors.

project.name: Counterchange Tessellation Dream
project.description:
1 in 2000 people are born with synesthesia, and I am one of them. This morphing Counterchange Tessellation is an invention of mine, something that stems from my visions as a synesthete. I experience patterns like these that are ever-flowing and changing to the music I am listening to.

🌌 Dive into a Universe of Visuals 🌌
You're not just buying a piece of art; you're getting a key to a universe of 414 trillion unique visual experiences. To put that in perspective, if you were to watch this animation non-stop for 80 years, the odds of seeing the same image twice would be less than getting struck by lightning—twice! It's a lottery of visuals you're unlikely to ever win, making each moment with this piece a rare treasure.

🌳 Sow Seeds of Change 🌳
A portion of initial proceeds and royalties will go towards planting trees. When you own this NFT, you're not just an art collector—you're a guardian of the Earth.

🎨 Unlock Exclusive Benefits 🎨
J2B token holders get an exclusive 15% off at our Store, savetheworldwithart.io. Contact us at jams2blues@savetheworldwithart.io to redeem your discount.

🌍 Join the Mission 🌍
Check out jams2blues.art for more ways to be a part of the movement.

Plant trees.
Support Artists.
Save The World With Art™.

project.name: Integration
project.description:
Random walkers located across the four sections of the screen cross and leave the canvas, mixing and integrating as they go. 
Based on their veolocity, some Walkers will stay put, some will immediately exit to the side, others will mix and mingle. 
I see this as the way different types of people spend their lives, some mingling and mixing with a long path symbolising a story to tell. 
Others stay put, seemingly content to remain where they begin or perhaps not brave enough to explore the other corners of their realm.

project.name: Celestial Kaleidoscope
project.description:
"Celestial Kaleidoscope" is an extraordinary collection of 50 generative artworks that capture the unique essence of the cosmos through innovative algorithmic techniques. These works are the result of a masterful fusion of mathematics and creativity, giving rise to an extraordinary visual experience.

Each artwork is composed of a set of particles moving seemingly randomly yet structured against a white background, reminiscent of a blank canvas awaiting the artist's touch. The particles move with grace and fluidity, creating a sense of perpetual motion, much like the waves crashing on the golden sands of an untouched beach.

The color palette used in this collection is equally captivating. Deep blue and vibrant orange blend delicately, evoking the reflection of the sun on water and the ever-shifting hues of the sunset sky. These colors blend and overlap in a way that imparts a feeling of calm and serenity to the artworks.

Each piece is unique, yet they all share a mesmerizing quality that captures the viewer and transports them into a world of abstract beauty. The number of moving particles and their positions constantly change, creating a sense of evolution and alteration, akin to the tides rising and falling along the shore.

The artist has skillfully harnessed the algorithm to capture the magic and complexity of the cosmos, creating works that seem to come to life. When contemplating these pieces, one can almost hear the sound of crashing waves and feel the warmth of the sun on their skin.

'Celestial Kaleidoscope' is a collection that invites viewers to reflect on the beauty of nature and its immeasurable importance. These generative artworks serve as a reminder of how precious our planet is and inspire us to preserve and protect coastal and marine ecosystems. Ultimately, this collection is a tribute to the wonder of nature and a celebration of generative art as a means to explore the beauty and intricacy of the world that surrounds us."

project.name: Cycloids
project.description:
Retro animating Cycloids. Interactive, drag to explore. 
Features: 
Each mint has it's own unique lighting
"Day" or rare "Night" mode
4 types of velocity of growth or contraction
25 possible palettes including 12 from the Studio Yorktown Color Town Hall

project.name: Vibrant Oscillations
project.description:
Each dot moves in a special pattern, following rules from math. 

The colors and paths are fixed but look random, creating a blend of order and surprise. 
It's like a dance of colors that you can enjoy again and again, and it will always be the same beautiful show.

project.name: Récurante Aléatoire
project.description:
Récurant dans l'ombre, aléatoire à la lumière,
La toile danse et s'épanouit sans frontière

This art piece blends recursion and randomness to craft a perpetually changing visual landscape. Like the poem suggests, it's akin to a dancing canvas that unfolds in unexpected directions. 

Each viewing feels new yet follows a numeric sequence, creating a digital kaleidoscope that surprises you every time you look.

© genix | sep 2023

project.name: Transcendence
project.description:
In pixels and hues, a dance unfolds,
A cosmic ballet where light is controlled.
Swaying in rhythm, yet breaking the mold,
Transcendence—where chaos and harmony are scrolled.

project.name: Aurora
project.description: Aurora, a generative typography art algorithm, draws inspiration from the captivating natural phenomena of the same name. It mimics the colorful lines and curves of the Aurora, crafting a mesmerizing tapestry that mirrors the breathtaking spectacle found in the night sky. Each curve in this algorithmic creation becomes a narrative of its own, evoking a sense of wonder and storytelling. With its graceful interplay of vivid hues ranging from soft pastels to vibrant neon shades, Aurora natural phenomena often emulates the enchanting colors seen during the early morning (Gm) and late evening (Gn) hours. This innovative algorithm reshapes a vast array of letters from diverse styles, scripts, and characteristics, producing a captivating typography art.

project.name: Crossing
project.description:
A bit of trigonometry combined with Perlin noise wrapped in a loop for tens of thousands of iterations

Native JS + Trigonometry + Perlin = ❤️

project.name: Lonely Night
project.description:
Ever had one of those nights where you're just by yourself, staring at a sky that's dark but also kinda magical?

That's what Lonely Night feels like. 
It's like each little shape is having its own quiet moment, doing its own thing. 
They might look alone, but put 'em all together and you've got this awesome, interconnected world. The colors? All about those deep blues and soft whites, kinda like a night sky but with a twist.

© genix | sep 2023

project.name: Inner Anarchy
project.description:
When I look at myself, immersed in a life surrounded by technology and drowning in desires, I feel my loss more acutely.
We have become distant from each other.
We were one, and now we are two.
We were close, and now we are far apart.
We were smooth, but now we are tangled.
We were simple, but now we are complicated.

Creating this work revives the memory of our separation for me.
I love your sharpness, just like the softness of our past.

- HARCHI 2023

project.name: Cohesion
project.description:
An art project focused on how each piece relates to one another and what it means to exist as is. Cohesion is comprised of multiple NFTs focused on minimal textures and color blocks, a common motif across totty's everyday series. Some pieces may be simplistic while others seemingly have their 'best parts' covered by artifacts. This collection reminds the viewer to consider how every individual piece of something connects to the broader whole and to see things for what they are as they exist.

The sum is greater than its parts.

project.name: Heart X Mind
project.description:
Inspired by the latest work of Erick Calderon (Snowfro) and Jordan Lyall .

A heart that falls in love.
A heart that can love.
A heart that breaks.
A heart that hurts.
A heart that experiences happiness.
A heart that sacrifices.
And the mind that thinks and the war that is always going on between the heart and the mind. A war between emotion and wisdom.

with love 
Reza

project.name: Iris
project.description: generative eye pupils

project.name: Blinds
project.description: The shapes and colors come together in a way that just grabs your attention, making everything feel both spontaneous and just as it should be. It's like finding order in a beautifully chaotic dance.

project.name: Semithings
project.description:
"Semithings" is a -quite formal- work of composition, shape and color, stirred by language and accumulation.

Conceptually:
I've just recently understood that my work is accumulation. Using cheap pieces to build complex stuff.

The concept of accumulation then made me think of the parallel with communication, how we spread or stack stories made of sentences made of words made of letters.

Also, while words are not the same as the things they name, describe or promise, they're also often MORE than the thing they represent.
Doubly so here, since once they start following my composition rules, they form abstract shapes with some underlying order below them.
And whenever we see abstract images, specially if they have some kind of logic or order, we try to recognize+classify them, comparing to previous experiences.
So, while "Semithings" are neither stick bundles nor anticyclones they could be said to look like such things and that's what our mind goes for.

Aesthetically:
I manipulated the color and light behaviors so the accumulation became one of brushstrokes or stamping. This way, I could better use and explore the "painting, coloring a canvas" gestures that I was after.

To avoid actual words interfering in the reading of the image, I wrote a sub-algorithm to generate artificial alphabets. Not quite asemic writing but something more "solid" that could be engraved on marble obelisks and the like.
It starts with a grid of 12x4 and a set of rules and preferences that draw paths in this grid. The characters, individuals, pieces.
Then each of these paths is improved (actually decayed) to have more of a "written" or personal feel.

I locked the algorithm to variation 22*, meaning all outputs are made of the same (28) pieces, or written in a shared alphabet if you will.

Then I print, deform, flatten, stretch, rotate and scale those 28 bases    -following a very loose interpretation of speech bubbles- to generate Semithings.
                                       *my betting number

+++ PRESS "s" to save as png +++

projectScripts.script:
<pxW; x++){
    gridOnOff[x] = [];
    for(let y=0; y<pxH; y++){
      gridOnOff[x][y] = 0;
    }
  }
	cpx = 0; cpy = 0;//to avoid versions of a same letter
  gridOnOff[cpx][cpy] = 1;
  pixelLetters = [[cpx,cpy]];//0,0 for 1st
	
//Calc next cells
  while(!letterSolved){
  //movement
    push();
	  let np = false;
	  let col = 'black';
		let brk = 0;
	  while(!np){    //movement
	    axis = rrarr([0,1]);//Hor-Vert
	    dir = rrarr([-1,1]);
	    npx = cpx+axis*dir;
	    npy = cpy+(1-axis)*dir;
	    if(isInside(npx,pxW) && isInside(npy,pxH) &&//ask bfr lG[npx][npy] error
	      gridOnOff[npx][npy]==0 && isNotParal(npx, npy, axis)) {
	        np = true;//valid point
	        cpx = npx; cpy=npy;
	        gridOnOff[cpx][cpy] = 1;
					pixelLetters.push([cpx,cpy]);
	        brk = 0;
	    }
	    brk++;
	    if(brk>20){letterSolved = true; break;}//too many invalid => END
	  }
	  pop();
	}
	//re-center letters on 0,0
  for(let l= 0; l<pixelLetters.length; l++){
    pixelLetters[l][0] -= -0.5+(pxW)/2;
    pixelLetters[l][1] -= -0.5+(pxH)/2;
  }
}
function alpha0_2_unpixelate(){
	letterPath = [...pixelLetters];
	let tempA = [letterPath[0]];
	for(let pp=0; pp<letterPath.length-1; pp++){
		let p = letterPath[pp];
		let q = letterPath[pp+1];
		if(pp<letterPath.length-2){
			let r = letterPath[pp+2];
				tempA.push(r)
				pp+=1;
		} else {
				tempA.push(q)
		}
	}
	letterPath = [...tempA];//sanitized list, skips corners = has diagonals
}
function alpha0_3_calcLRpoints(){
  let p,q,usv,ang,pL,pR,info;
	inline = [];
  for (let pp=0; pp<letterPath.length-1; pp++){
		p = letterPath[pp];
		q = letterPath[pp+1];
		usv = createVector(q[0]-p[0],q[1]-p[1]);
    pL = createVector(0,0);
    pR = createVector(0,0);
    info = {
      center : [p[0],p[1]],
      angle : usv.heading(),
      softAngle : usv.heading(),
      perpL : 0,
      perpR : 0
    }
    inline.push(info);
  }
//+Add last point manually
	let xp = letterPath[letterPath.length-1];
  info = {
    center : [xp[0],xp[1]],
    angle : usv.heading(),
    softAngle : usv.heading(),
    perpL : 0,
    perpR : 0
  }
  inline.push(info);
// ----------------Now find crossings
  p = inline[0];//pL pR only for pt ZERO. nxts'll come from paral crossing
  pc = p.center;
  pa = p.angle;
  p.perpL = createVector(pc[0]+pen*cos(pa-(PI/2)),pc[1]+pen*sin(pa-(PI/2)));//perpend
  p.perpR = createVector(pc[0]-pen*cos(pa-(PI/2)),pc[1]-pen*sin(pa-(PI/2)));//perpend
  
  //
  for(let p=1; p<inline.length; p++){
    co = inline[p];
    cp = co.center;
    ca = co.angle;
    po = inline[p-1];
    pa = po.angle;

    let newA = ((pa+ca)/2)-(PI/2);
    penb = 4;//regular 
    co.perpL = createVector(cp[0]+penb*cos(newA),cp[1]+penb*sin(newA));
    co.perpR = createVector(cp[0]-penb*cos(newA),cp[1]-penb*sin(newA));
    co.softAngle = newA;
  }
    
  for(let p=0; p<inline.length-1; p++){
    co = inline[p];
    ca = co.angle;
    l1 = co.perpL; 
    r1 = co.perpR;
    l2 = createVector(l1.x+8*cos(ca),l1.y+8*sin(ca));
    r2 = createVector(r1.x+8*cos(ca),r1.y+8*sin(ca));
    if(show){showParallels(l1,l2,r1,r2);}

    no = inline[p+1];
    perp1 = no.perpL;
    perp2 = no.perpR;
    if(show){showPerpendicular(perp1,perp2);}
      doWhat = [0,'no.perpL = hitPoint'];
      doDont = lineLineIntersect(perp1.x, perp1.y, perp2.x, perp2.y, l1.x, l1.y, l2.x, l2.y);
      eval(doWhat[doDont*1]);
//AltIf
      doWhat = [0,'no.perpR = hitPoint'];
      doDont = lineLineIntersect(perp1.x, perp1.y, perp2.x, perp2.y, r1.x, r1.y, r2.x, r2.y);
      eval(doWhat[doDont*1]);
  }    
//--SAVE LETTERS
  lps = []; rps = [];
  for(let p=0; p<inline.length; p++){
    lp = inline[p].perpL;
    rp = inline[p].perpR;
    lps.push(lp);
    rps.push(rp);
  }
  info = {
    gridOnOff: gridOnOff,
    letterPath: letterPath,
    lps: lps,
    rps: rps,
    top3d : 0,
    outline : 0,
    blockOutline : 0
  }
  alfabet.push(info);
}

function alpha1_uniqueFont(){
  for(let k=0; k<alfabet.length; k++){
    let l = alfabet[k];
    lps = []; rps = [];
    top3d = [];
    blockLps = []; blockRps = [];
    for(let p=0; p<l.lps.length; p++){
      lp = l.lps[p];
      rp = l.rps[p];
      lps.push(lp);
      rps.push(rp);
      top3d.push(lp);
      top3d.push(rp);
  //--block noise outlines
      bl = p5.Vector.lerp(lp,rp,rr2(-1,-0.5));
      br = p5.Vector.lerp(lp,rp,rr2(1.0,1.5));
      blockLps.push(bl);
      blockRps.push(br);
    } 
  //--default outline  
  	rpsrev =  [...rps].reverse();
  	outline = [...lps,...rpsrev];
  //--block outlines
  	rpsrev =  [...blockRps].reverse();
  	blockOutline = [...blockLps,...rpsrev];
  
    l.top3d = top3d;
    l.outline = outline;
    l.blockOutline = blockOutline;
  }
}

    graffiti.fill((255*th[th.length-1]));//color right before white = smoother font rendering in THmode
    graffiti.translate(fSize*pxW*0.5,pxH*(tmargin));//half char R, margin T
    graffiti.scale(cw/(cols*pxW));
    for(let l=0; l<(cols*rows); l++){

//AltIf

function mod0_makeModels(){
  skin = graffiti;
  for(let ll=0; ll<alfabet.length; ll++){
    polygons[ll] = [...alfabet[ll].blockOutline];
    peripartials.push(0);
    mod0_1_modelFactory(ll);
  }  
}

function mod0_1_modelFactory(ll){
    let l = polygons[ll];
    let verts = [];
    let h = pxW;//height of the "base" block
    let hmL = 1;//hmLevels: block=1, can be more
    hmL = 3;
    let lh = h/hmL;//level height
    let cols = l.length;
    let rows = hmL+1;//this is for Blocks. Prisms will copy 1st and Last rows ("u"s)
    for(let col=0; col<cols; col++){
      verts[col] = [];
      for(let row=0; row<rows; row++){
        info = {
          x : 0,
          y : 0,
          z : 0,
          u : 0,
          v : 0
        }
        verts[col].push(info);
      }
    }

row = 0;
peripartial = 0;
    for(let col=0; col<cols; col++){
      p = l[col%cols];
        if(col!=0){
          o = l[(col-1)%cols];
          peripartial += p5.Vector.dist(o,p);
        }
        u = 1*peripartial/skin.width;
        verts[col][row].x = p.x*1;
        verts[col][row].z = p.y*1;
        verts[col][row].u = u;
    }
    // Extend to 1st and save to letter!
      p = l[l.length-1];
      q = l[0];
      peripartial += p5.Vector.dist(p,q);
      peripartials[ll] = peripartial;    
    
col = 0
    for(let row=0; row<rows; row++){//Block = only 2 rows (0,1)
      verts[col][row].y = -row*lh + h/2;//row*lh - h/2 to notFLIP
      verts[col][row].v = 1*row*h/(rows*skin.height);
    }
    
//COMPLETE GRID
    for(let col=0; col<cols; col++){
      for(let row=0; row<rows; row++){
        factor = 1;
        if(row==0 || row == rows-1){factor = 0;}
        verts[col][row].x = verts[col][0].x+rr2(-1,1)*factor;
        verts[col][row].y = verts[0][row].y+rr2(-1,1)*factor;
        verts[col][row].z = verts[col][0].z+rr2(-1,1)*factor;
        verts[col][row].u = verts[col][0].u*1;
        verts[col][row].v = verts[0][row].v*1;
      }
    }    
    
  mod0_1_1_buildFlat(ll,verts,cols);
  mod0_1_2_buildPrism(ll,verts,cols,rows,1);//block
  mod0_1_2_buildPrism(ll,verts,cols,rows,hmL);//prism
}

function mod0_1_1_buildFlat(ll,verts,cols){
    l = polygons[ll];
    
  window['L'+ll+'F'] = buildGeometry('flashy'+ll, (builder) => {
  	builder.push();    
    for(let tp=0; tp<(cols/2)-1; tp++){//perimeter to paral strip
      let bp = (cols-tp)-1;
      let p0 = verts[tp][0];//    p0----p3
      let p1 = verts[bp-1][0];//  |      |
      let p2 = verts[bp][0];//    p2----p1
      let p3 = verts[tp+1][0];
      ufactor = 1/skin.width;
      vfactor = 1/skin.height;
      builder.beginShape();
        builder.vertex(p0.x,-pxW/2,p0.z,p0.x*ufactor,p0.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p1.x,-pxW/2,p1.z,p1.x*ufactor,p1.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p2.x,-pxW/2,p2.z,p2.x*ufactor,p2.z*vfactor);
      builder.endShape();
      builder.beginShape();
        builder.vertex(p0.x,-pxW/2,p0.z,p0.x*ufactor,p0.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p3.x,-pxW/2,p3.z,p3.x*ufactor,p3.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p1.x,-pxW/2,p1.z,p1.x*ufactor,p1.z*vfactor);
      builder.endShape();
      
      builder.beginShape();
        builder.vertex(p0.x, pxW/2,p0.z,p0.x*ufactor,p0.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p2.x, pxW/2,p2.z,p2.x*ufactor,p2.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p1.x, pxW/2,p1.z,p1.x*ufactor,p1.z*vfactor);
      builder.endShape();
      builder.beginShape();
        builder.vertex(p0.x, pxW/2,p0.z,p0.x*ufactor,p0.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p1.x, pxW/2,p1.z,p1.x*ufactor,p1.z*vfactor);
        builder.vertex(p3.x, pxW/2,p3.z,p3.x*ufactor,p3.z*vfactor);
      builder.endShape();        

    }

  	builder.pop()
  })
  window['L'+ll+'F'].computeNormals()
}

function mod0_1_2_buildPrism(ll,verts,cols,rows,hmL){
    l = polygons[ll];
    let shapeType = ll+'P';
    if(hmL==1){shapeType = ll+'B';}
    
  window['L'+shapeType] = buildGeometry('prism'+shapeType, (builder) => {
  	builder.push();    
//now create triangles Clockwise on Levels
    for(let cL=1; cL<=hmL; cL++){
      r0 = cL-1;//top row of the level
      r1 = cL;//foot row
        //if hmL == 1, block, use only r0 = 0 and r1 = last row
      if (hmL == 1){
        r0 = 0;
        r1 = rows-1;
      }  
        
      for(let col=cols; col>=1; col--){
      // for(let col=0; col<=cols; col++){//close last with 1st
        // BUT MUST CHANGE UVS after LAST PT or U is fucked
        c0 = col%cols;
        c1 = (c0+1)%cols;
        p0 = verts[c0][r0];//  p0----p3
        p1 = verts[c1][r1];//  |      |
        p2 = verts[c0][r1];//  p2----p1
        p3 = verts[c1][r0];
        if(col==cols-1){//fix "u" for closing column!
          p3.u = 1*peripartials[ll]/skin.width;
          p1.u = 1*peripartials[ll]/skin.width;
        }
//F DO IT
        builder.beginShape();
          builder.vertex(p0.x,p0.y,p0.z,p0.u,p0.v);
          builder.vertex(p1.x,p1.y,p1.z,p1.u,p1.v);
          builder.vertex(p2.x,p2.y,p2.z,p2.u,p2.v);
        builder.endShape();
        builder.beginShape();
          builder.vertex(p0.x,p0.y,p0.z,p0.u,p0.v);
          builder.vertex(p3.x,p3.y,p3.z,p3.u,p3.v);
          builder.vertex(p1.x,p1.y,p1.z,p1.u,p1.v);
        builder.endShape();
      }
    }
  	builder.pop()
  })
  window['L'+shapeType].computeNormals()
}

function drawBkg(){
    x0 = cw*margin; x1 = cw-(cw*margin);
    y0 = cw*margin; y1 = ch-(cw*margin);
  // compBkg.shader(bkgShader)
  compBkg.noStroke();
  compBkg.fill(255);
	//----------BKG planes
    bkgShader.setUniform('lightPos', [800,600,-40]);
    bkgShader.setUniform('offPos', [0,0.5]);
    bkgShader.setUniform('img', skin);
    bkgShader.setUniform('imgOnOff', 1);        
    bkgShader.setUniform('offskl', [1,1]);

    compBkg.push()

    bkgShader.setUniform('notBkg', 0);
    bkgShader.setUniform('objType', [1]);
    bkgShader.setUniform('bkgColor', [0.9,0.9,0.9,1]);
    if(whichPal=='Ink'){
      bkgShader.setUniform('bkgColor', [0.5,0.5,0.5,1]);
    }

    bkgShader.setUniform('offskl', [0.2,0.2]);
    compBkg.plane(cw,ch);
    // compBkg.plane(cw*1.3/ratio,ch*1.3/ratio);
    compBkg.translate(0,0,0.01);

    let ac = [...allColors];
    bkgShader.setUniform('objType', [2]);
    bkgShader.setUniform('bkgColor', [ac[0],ac[1],ac[2],1]);
    if(whichPal=='Ink'){
      bkgShader.setUniform('bkgColor', [0.9,0.9,0.9,1]);
    }
    adv = 8;
    
    compBkg.plane(x1-x0,y1-y0);
    compBkg.translate(-cw/2,-ch/2,0);
let kk = rrarr([-1,1]);
kk = -1;
for(let dir=-1; dir<=1; dir+=2){
  yp = y0;
  xp = x0;
  if((dir*kk)>0){yp = y1; xp = x1;}
  compBkg.beginShape(TRIANGLE_STRIP);
    compBkg.vertex(x0,yp,0);
    p0=x0+adv*rr2(2,3);
    for(let px = p0; px<x1; px+=adv){
      factor = 1;
      dis = x1-px;
      if(dis<(adv*3)){factor = dis/(adv*3);}
      let py = yp + factor*kk*dir*noise(px*0.009)*adv*0.5;
      compBkg.vertex(px,py,0);
      compBkg.vertex(px,yp,0);
    }
    compBkg.vertex(x1,yp,0);
  compBkg.endShape();
  
  compBkg.beginShape(TRIANGLE_STRIP);
    compBkg.vertex(xp,y0,0);
    p0=y0+adv*rr2(2,3);
    for(let py = p0; py<y1; py+=adv){
      factor = 1;
      dis = y1-py;
      if(dis<(adv*4/ratio)){factor = dis/(adv*4/ratio);}
      let px = xp + factor*kk*dir*noise(py*0.009)*adv*0.4*ratio;
      compBkg.vertex(px,py,0);
      compBkg.vertex(xp,py,0);
    }
    compBkg.vertex(xp,y1,0);
  compBkg.endShape();
  
  
}
      
    compBkg.pop()
    
    
}
function drawGaze(){
collect.push();
let h,s,b;
h = hue(myPal[1]);
s = saturation(myPal[1]);
b = brightness(myPal[1]);
collect.stroke(myPal[1]);

  if(whichPal=='Ink'){
    collect.stroke(100);
  }
  else {
    if(myPal[1]=='#000000' || myPal[1]=='#001219'){
      collect.blendMode(MULTIPLY);
      collect.stroke(10);
    } 
  }
  
  for(let c=0; c<10; c++){
    collect.push();
    maxGx = rr2(50,650);
    maxGy = 700-maxGx;
  let blown = 1;
    if(whichPal=='Ink'){
      blown = 1;
    }
    else {
      if(b<80){
        blown = 2;
        if(myPal[1]=='#ca6702' || myPal[1]=='#ee9b00' 
        || myPal[1]=='#c80003' || myPal[1]=='#CC8000'){
          blown = 1.6;
        }
        if(myPal[1]=='#005f73'){
          blown = 3;
        }
      }
    }
    x0 = cw; x1 = cw-(cw);
    y0 = cw; y1 = ch-(cw);
//----gaze INSIDE frame
cex = rr2(0,cw-maxGx);
cey = rr2(0,ch-maxGy);

if(c%3==0){//force gazes in corners
  cs = c/3;
  xs = [0,0,cw-maxGx,cw-maxGx];
  ys = [0,ch-maxGy,0,ch-maxGy];
  cex = xs[cs];
  cey = ys[cs];
}
    gsk = min(10,(maxGx+maxGy)/100);
    myPs = [];
    for(let px=0; px<maxGx; px+=gsk){
      myPsx = [];
      for(let py=0; py<maxGy; py+=gsk){
        nx = noise(px*0.005,py*0.005)*8*gsk-(4*gsk);
        ny = noise(py*0.005,px*0.005)*8*gsk-(4*gsk);
        gx=cex+px+nx;
        gy=cey+py+ny;
        g = createVector(gx,gy);
        myPsx.push(g);
      }
      myPs.push(myPsx);
    }

    for(let gx=0; gx<myPs.length-1; gx++){
      for(let gy=0; gy<myPs[gx].length-1; gy++){
        let p = myPs[gx][gy];
        let b = myPs[gx][gy+1];
        let r = myPs[gx+1][gy];
        collect.strokeWeight(blown*rr()/8);
        collect.line(p.x,p.y,r.x,r.y);
        collect.line(p.x,p.y,b.x,b.y);
      }
    }
    collect.pop();
  }
collect.pop();  
}

project.name: Semithings
project.description:
"Semithings" is a -quite formal- work of composition, shape and color, stirred by language and accumulation.

Conceptually:
I've just recently understood that my work is accumulation. Using cheap pieces to build complex stuff.

The concept of accumulation then made me think of the parallel with communication, how we spread or stack stories made of sentences made of words made of letters.

Also, while words are not the same as the things they name, describe or promise, they're also often MORE than the thing they represent.
Doubly so here, since once they start following my composition rules, they form abstract shapes with some underlying order below them.
And whenever we see abstract images, specially if they have some kind of logic or order, we try to recognize+classify them, comparing to previous experiences.
So, while "Semithings" are neither stick bundles nor anticyclones they could be said to look like such things and that's what our mind goes for.

Aesthetically:
I manipulated the color and light behaviors so the accumulation became one of brushstrokes or stamping. This way, I could better use and explore the "painting, coloring a canvas" gestures that I was after.

To avoid actual words interfering in the reading of the image, I wrote a sub-algorithm to generate artificial alphabets. Not quite asemic writing but something more "solid" that could be engraved on marble obelisks and the like.
It starts with a grid of 12x4 and a set of rules and preferences that draw paths in this grid. The characters, individuals, pieces.
Then each of these paths is improved (actually decayed) to have more of a "written" or personal feel.

I locked the algorithm to variation 22*, meaning all outputs are made of the same (28) pieces, or written in a shared alphabet if you will.

Then I print, deform, flatten, stretch, rotate and scale those 28 bases    -following a very loose interpretation of speech bubbles- to generate Semithings.
                                       *my betting number

+++ PRESS "s" to save as png +++

project.name: Droplets in Circles
project.description:
My artwork echoes the entrancing caustics dancing beneath the water's surface, a poetic testament to the world's hidden splendors. 
made in p5.js

project.name: Lotus Whispers
project.description:
This artwork invites you on a reflective journey, much like the slow, graceful unfolding of a lotus flower's petals. It draws its inspiration from the lotus, a symbol that represents our connection to our past and the challenges we encounter throughout life.

Similar to the lotus emerging from murky waters, this artwork mirrors the personal journey of self-discovery and growth. It serves as a reminder that even during life's most challenging moments, there's a path towards enlightenment and spiritual awakening.

As you observe the gradual revelation of the lotus within the artwork, think of it as an invitation to explore your own inner self. Just as the lotus unveils its beauty over time, this artwork encourages us to embark on our own unique journey of self-discovery.

In essence, this visual masterpiece meditates on the idea that each of us possesses the potential to bloom and uncover our inner beauty, even when faced with life's difficulties. It reminds us that, like the lotus, our inner selves can radiate light and grace, regardless of the circumstances we encounter.

project.name: Algebraic Swirls
project.description:
Square roots and signs,
In lines of code, they intertwine.
Particles dance in deterministic lines,
Mapping x to y, across space and time.

Parameters set, a trio in hand,
Each particle follows a secret command.
Ny from x is subtracted and grown,
Nx takes a root, its essence is shown.

In a canvas broad, they draw and weave,
A tale of motion you almost believe.
Though algorithms their fates control,
A universe in code, with math as its soul.

Wait 20 seconds, let the screen unveil.

project.name: Beyond the compass
project.description:
Step into a world where simplicity becomes an exquisite form of artistic expression, where the unassuming circle transcends its conventional confines to become a canvas of limitless possibilities. "Beyond the compass" is a collection that beckons you to journey through the mesmerizing realm of circles, semi-circles, and arcs, where serenity and innovation intertwine in a dance of graceful curves.

Each piece within this collection is a testament to the beauty that can be achieved through dedication and perseverance. It's more than just a showcase of art; it's a celebration of a personal triumph. "Beyond the compass" unites the finesse of fine art with the precision of coding, birthing a collection that serves as a wellspring of motivation. Like ripples in a tranquil pond, these artworks emanate a sense of calm and harmony, inviting viewers to pause, reflect, and find solace in the artistry of simplicity.

The subtle elegance of these circular creations reflects not just the artist's hand, but also the artist's heart. The collection is a testament to the extraordinary beauty that can emerge from the ordinary, a reminder that within every circle lies a world of potential waiting to be discovered, and a reminder that the most remarkable achievements often arise from the simplest forms. 

As you acquire these meticulously crafted pieces, you become part of a narrative that bridges technology and aesthetics, simplicity and complexity. Each work represents the potential inherent in the simplest of shapes, a reminder that greatness often emerges from humble beginnings. The benefits extend beyond aesthetic pleasure. As a holder of these unique creations, you infuse your spaces with the tranquility and innovation that "Beyond the compass" embodies. The gentle curves serve as a visual balm, creating environments that inspire creativity and calm contemplation. Moreover, your support carries the spirit of innovation and determination — a testament to the heights reached when one dedicates themselves to their craft.

project.name: Classic generative landscape V3
project.description: I have always loved the classic generative landscape - "mountain, planet" and it's time for the third part! The work is done in the lo-fi minimalism style - a minimum of colors + grainy texture.

project.name: Numeri
project.description:
"Numeri" è la mia collezione di 1024 opere d'arte generativa. In questa composizione ho cercato di fondere la matematica all'arte. Ogni opera che acquisterai è unica, perché nasce da un algoritmo che genera un numero casuale di cifre e le posiziona in modo altrettanto casuale su uno sfondo colorato.
Ogni pezzo di questa collezione è unico nel suo genere, animato dalla generazione di numeri casuali che vengono visualizzati in punti scelti a caso sullo schermo. Questo processo dinamico porta a un’opera d’arte in continua evoluzione, dove ogni numero cambia in modo sottile ma significativo la composizione del pezzo.
Il colore dello sfondo cambia ad ogni creazione, grazie alla generazione di tre numeri casuali che determinano i valori RGB. Questo dona ad ogni pezzo un’atmosfera unica, con una tavolozza di colori che può variare da toni rilassanti e morbidi a combinazioni audaci e vibranti.
“Numeri” è il mio omaggio all’incontro tra arte e scienza.
Esplora le infinite possibilità dell’arte generativa, un campo che sfrutta gli algoritmi per creare pezzi unici.
Questa collezione ci invita a riflettere sul ruolo importante che la tecnologia e i dati hanno nelle nostre vite e sulla bellezza inaspettata che può nascere da questa fusione.

project.name: My life(old)
project.description: Shapes are always changing, change is their normal state, just like us. Even though we might not change on the outside, on the inside we are always different. And each piece that composes this chaos creates the beauty that is life, a heap of shapes, colors, textures that create a beautiful form of what exists, existed and will exist. Where chaos creates the moment and the beauty of being unique and changeable

project.name: A land to live in
project.description: "A land to live in" is your digital safe space, where you can find peace and tranquility in a piece of generative art.You can call it home, safe zone, land or whatever you like, because it is your own realm.

project.name: Neon Puzzles
project.description:
'Neon Puzzles' is a long-form generative art collection brought to life thanks to the mesmerizing magic of p5.js. A world where geometry shows off its groovy side, swaying to the beat of neon daydreams. Within this collection, every piece is a living canvas, a complex tapestry woven with vibrant neon hues and dynamic shapes that pulse and flow like a digital jam session.

'Neon Puzzles' serves as a tribute to the quirky love affair between technology and artistic flair. As you dive into the collection, you'll witness a grid filled with geometric marvels that appear to inhale and exhale. The composition ripples with motion, delivering a visual spectacle that transports you to a neon-lit utopia.

The grid responds in real-time, twisting and reshaping itself with your every whim. The underlying logic governing these shapes adjusts dynamically, birthing fresh compositions and forms, ensuring that no two moments spent with 'Neon Puzzles' are ever identical.

This collection extends an open invitation to explore a realm where technology shares a dance with imagination, where neon hues and geometry unite in an enthralling spectacle of light and motion.

CONTROLS
Spacebar: Disable interaction
a: Disable Animation
Arrow Down: Save canvas

project.name: Resonance
project.description:
"In every human encounter, we carry the potential to catalyze evolution. Through the alchemical journey of the soul, we transcend—from pain to power, wounds to wisdom, death to rebirth, hate to love, lost to discovery."

'Resonance', a generative art collection created with p5.js, dives deep into the nexus of artistic expression and the profound potency of resonance. The artworks in this collection evoke images of intricate grids and cerebral lazes—patterns of thought, some so intense that they paralyze, while others liberate, propelling us towards action. These representations mirror the omnipresent dichotomy of confinement and freedom we wrestle with in our minds.

These generative forms, with their precision and calculated symmetries, present a vision both chilling and enlightening—like staring into a soul mechanized. They challenge the viewer to meditate on our intrinsic human urge for control, efficiency, and the elusive pursuit of perfection. 

For many, this quest for belonging and acceptance, hidden behind perfectionism, is a painful battle—a fight never won. Such a struggle pushes us to change, to adapt, to metamorphose, often at the cost of our true selves. This story deeply resonates with the creator's journey. Born in Bogota, Colombia, her life has been a collage of experiences. From the roles of engineer, immigrant, mother, friend and partner, to the realm of an artist. This tapestry of experiences is woven into the fabric of 'Resonance'.

Art has unlocked a universe of shared wisdom, connecting artists with kindred spirits across the globe. It is within this space that 'Resonance' finds its true home—a collection where each piece is a symphony of basic geometry juxtaposed with vivid hues and gradients, mirroring the iterative dance of life. It's an ode to our journey, to embracing our flaws and recognizing that it is through our imperfections that we find completeness. The essence of 'Resonance' is one of connection, gratitude, strength, and the miracles that dance on the edge of the everyday.

project.name: Symphony of Circles
project.description:
A tapestry of geometry and light unfurls, each circle acting as a note in a grand visual opus.
Translucency dances with hue, creating a ballet of overlapping worlds.
Spectral gradients unveil themselves like ethereal veils, cloaking shapes in a luminous mist.
The composition oscillates between chaotic whirls and harmonious alignments, embodying the delicate balance between order and entropy.
The final crescendo? A captivating symphony for the eyes.

project.name: Verdant Horizons
project.description:
In Verdant Horizons, hills roll like whispers,
Painted in shades where the sun's kiss lingers.
The sky, a canvas of heavenly hues,
Bears light's embrace in soft pinks and blues.

Each hill is a story, a lifetime, a breath,
A stretch of the Earth, a break in the depth.
Randomly etched by algorithmic hand,
This landscape transcends what's naturally planned.

Gleams dance in the air, their shimmer, divine,
As if time's been caught in an endless twine.
It's more than a scene; it's a meditative state,
A realm where destiny and design integrate.

In Verdant Horizons, the horizon's not a line,
But a curve of potential where dreams intertwine.
Here, even the trees grow in digital soil,
In a world where nature and numbers uncoil.
